definitions.definition: weighing a lot; difficult to lift or move

examples.text: a **heavy weight/load**
She was struggling with a heavy suitcase.
My brother is much heavier than me.
He tried to push the heavy door open.
**How heavy** is it *(= how much does it weigh)*?
Her father carried a **heavy burden** of responsibility.
The bottles of wine made the bag even heavier.
You're getting too heavy to carry!
She felt her eyelids growing heavy (= she was getting sleepy).

definitions.definition: more or worse than usual in amount, degree, etc.

examples.text: the noise of **heavy traffic**
**heavy rain/rainfall/snow**
the effects of **heavy drinking**
There was **heavy fighting** in the capital last night.
The British suffered **heavy losses** in the battle.
His unit came under **heavy fire** from insurgents.
The penalty for speeding can be a heavy fine.
She spoke with heavy irony.

definitions.definition: doing the thing mentioned more, or more deeply, than usual

examples.text: a **heavy drinker/smoker**
a heavy sleeper

definitions.definition: large and solid

examples.text: big, dark rooms full of heavy furniture
He was tall and strong, with heavy features.

definitions.definition: thick

examples.text: heavy curtains
a heavy coat

definitions.definition: full of or loaded with something

examples.text: trees heavy with apples
The air was heavy with the scent of flowers.
His voice was heavy with sarcasm.
She was heavy with child *(= pregnant)*.

definitions.definition: large and powerful

examples.text: a wide range of engines and **heavy machinery/equipment**
heavy lorries/trucks

definitions.definition: involving a lot of work or activity; very busy

examples.text: a heavy schedule
She'd had a heavy day.

definitions.definition: hard, especially because it requires a lot of physical strength

examples.text: **heavy lifting**
A gardener comes in to do the heavy work for me.

definitions.definition: falling or hitting something with a lot of force

examples.text: a heavy fall/blow

definitions.definition: large in amount or very solid

examples.text: a heavy lunch/dinner/meal
Avoid heavy foods that are difficult to digest.

definitions.definition: carrying heavy weapons

examples.text: the heavy infantry/cavalry

definitions.definition: loud and deep

examples.text: **heavy breathing**
a heavy groan/sigh

definitions.definition: using a lot of something

examples.text: Older cars are heavy on gas.
Don't go so heavy on the garlic.

definitions.definition: serious; difficult to understand or enjoy

examples.text: We found the play very heavy.
The discussion got a little heavy.

definitions.definition: dangerous because of big waves, etc.

examples.text: strong winds and heavy seas
The heavy Atlantic swells pounded the beach.

definitions.definition: hot and without enough fresh air, in a way that feels unpleasant

examples.text: It's very heavy—I think there'll be a storm.

definitions.definition: wet, sticky and difficult to dig or to move over
very strict and severe

examples.text: Don't be so heavy on her—it wasn't her fault.

definitions.definition: to become very serious, because strong feelings are involved

examples.text: They started shouting at me. It got very heavy.
Then he got heavy and tried to kiss me.
Things were starting to get a bit heavy so I decided to leave.

definitions.definition: to have a difficult problem that makes you worried or unhappy but that you have to deal with

examples.text: We all have our crosses to bear.

definitions.definition: used to describe somebody/something that is difficult to deal with or understand

examples.text: She's a bit heavy going.
I found the course rather heavy going.

definitions.definition: a way of doing something or of treating people that is much stronger and less sensitive than it needs to be

examples.text: the heavy hand of management

definitions.definition: a very sad feeling

examples.text: I returned home with a heavy heart.

definitions.definition: a group of strong, often violent people employed to do something such as protect somebody
a situation when people do not say anything, but feel embarrassed or uncomfortable
to seem to find something more difficult or complicated than it needs to be

examples.text: People in this country make such heavy weather of learning languages.

definitions.definition: to have a bad effect on somebody/something; to cause a lot of damage, deaths, pain, etc.

examples.text: Illness had taken a heavy toll on her.
The recession is taking its toll on the housing markets.
The pressure of fame can take a terrible toll.

wordOrigin: Old English hefig, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch hevig, also to heave.
